awd_titl_txt: Statistical Design, Sampling, and Analysis for Large Scale Experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
In the big data paradigm, even the controlled experiments can become large-scale, in the sense that the sample size is massive, and the dimension of the input variables is high. Such "big data" problem challenges many statistical approaches and significantly increases the amount of computation in estimation and inference. In this project, the PI focuses on specific instances of large-scale experiments and develops a set of novel theories and methodologies on experimental design, sampling, and analysis. The research has two major parts. In Part 1, the PI focuses on the type of experiments that contains a large dimension of covariate variables. For example, in a clinical trial, the covariates can be patients' rich medical history. How should the treatment settings be assigned to each patient? The PI provides the answer through a general experimental design framework so that the treatment effects are estimated accurately despite the influence of the covariates. In Part 2, the PI focuses on the Gaussian Process (GP) regression, one of the most popular statistical learning tools. The computation required is prohibitive for analyzing large-scale experiments such as the climate model simulations. The PI develops a dimension reduction framework and an active learning method that significantly improves the efficiency and accuracy of the GP model.


Three major methodologies are considered. In Parts 1-3, the PI introduces a new discrepancy-based design to achieve covariate balance for experiments with a large dimension of covariates. The discrepancy criterion also has appealing theoretical properties that lead to a more accurate estimation of the parameters including both treatment effects and covariates' effects. Optimal design algorithms are developed for both offline and online experiments. In Part 4, the PI develops a novel dimension reduction method that finds the optimal convex combination of low-dimension kernel functions for the GP model. It is shown that the proposed method is a significantly less computational and more accurate approximation of certain types of underlying functions. In  Part 5, an active learning method based on the generalized Cook's Distance is developed for the GP regression. It is more efficient than the standard random sampling method. The research is novel in ideas, rigorous in theories, and useful in practice, and will open new directions in the statistical design and analysis of experiments area. The PI has a detailed education plan to develop new course modules, tutorials, and workshops based on the research products from this project. The research outcomes are readily applicable to a variety of scientific, engineering, medicine and other fields where large-scale data collection and analysis are demanded.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Supported by this NSF grant, our research initiative embarks on a series of captivating projects that illuminate the real-world impact of advanced statistical methods, driven by five major goals:

  1. Innovative Experimental Design: Our project strives to devise novel statistical experimental design methods tailored for complex statistical models and high-dimensional inputs.
  2. Adaptive Learning Models: We aim to create statistical learning models handling scenarios with large input dimensions, copious data, and response variables that are both heterogeneous and highly nonlinear.
  3. Robust Supervised Learning: The project endeavors to develop supervised learning models characterized by robustness to outliers in the presence of high-dimensional input and diverse response variables.
  4. Bayesian Sampling Techniques: New sampling methods for Bayesian inference and the abstraction of high-quality subsamples from vast datasets are in the pipeline to facilitate statistical learning.
  5. Real-world Application: Applying the proposed statistical methodologies, including experimental design, learning, and sampling methods, to tangible real-world applications is a key objective.

To realize these goals, our research has yielded a suite of statistical methodology works. We have developed a series of methods focusing on the design and analysis of experiments for various complex applications. They include an active learning method to discover physical laws, i.e., differential equations, different kinds of design methods for A/B testing experiments, a new optimal design for generalized linear models, and an optimal design for experiments with quantitative and qualitative responses. Several new statistical learning models have been created, such as a generative learning model for mixed responses and Bayesian modeling via latent variable for mixed responses. We also explored a new research domain in approximate inference for the Bayesian framework. Specifically, we introduced a new variational inference framework, called energetic variational inference. Using this new variational inference tool, we developed two different deterministic sampling tools that can also be used for generative learning and a new approach to estimate and make inferences for the Gaussian process regression model.

In our pursuit of societal benefit through data science, we developed a new strategy for scarce resource allocation which aims to create a synergistic intervention strategy that gives vulnerable populations higher priority in medical resource distribution. We also created a new fairness machine learning model based on the classic MARS model.

These works underscore the broad applicability and critical impact of statistical methodologies across various domains, including but not limited to physics, chemistry, material science, health care, etc. They have demonstrated advancements in active learning, experimental design, statistical learning, Bayesian computation, and other related areas in statistics and data science.

With the support of this NSF award, several Ph.D. students and undergraduate students were supported and trained in the domain of applied mathematics, statistics, and data science. New curriculums were developed by PI Kang and now are essential to the educational programs Master of Data Science and B.S. in Data Science at Illinois Institute of Technology. Kang has also developed new tutorials and course modules on the statistical design of experiments and advanced machine-learning models. Kang has made a significant effort to engage industrial professionals and pass the latest research results to data science professionals.
